52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Arsenic Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 10A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 10A and 10C represent the concentration of arsenic detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 10B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|report

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of arsenic (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 0.48 micrograms per gram and 0.1 micrograms per gram in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|T. D. Martin
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|C.A. Brockhoff
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|J.T. Creed
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|EMMC Methods Work Group
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubdate|1994

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://www.accustandard.com/asi/pdfs/epa_methods/200_7
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|J.T. Creed

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|T.D. Martin
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubdate|1994

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|10A - Arsenic in dry weight (micrograms per gram) from largemouth bass (LMB; Micropterus salmoides), blue catfish (CAT; Ictalurus furcatus), and striped mullet (MUL; Mugil cephalus) collected from Davis Pond postdiversion sites from December 2007 through February 2009. The horizontal line represents the 85th percentile in dry weight from the National Contaminant Biomonitoring Program (Schmitt and Brumbaugh, 1990); for arsenic it is 0.93 micrograms per gram. For arsenic concentration data, see Figure 10C (Jenkins and others, 2011).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61fe3.xml|/metadata/distinfo/distliab|Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Boron Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 12A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 12A and 12C represent the concentration of boron detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 12B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/useconst|Any person using the information here should fully understand the data collection and compilation procedures, as described in these metadata, before beginning analyses. The burden for determining fitness of use lies entirely with the user. For purposes of publication or dissemination, citations or credit should be given to the U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|report
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2008/5067/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of boron (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 1.42 micrograms per gram and 1.0 micrograms per gram in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|T. D. Martin

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ce4b063f258e61feb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|EMMC Methods Work Group

It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Iron Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 16A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 16A and 16C represent the concentration of iron detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 16B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|report
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|2008-5067
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2008/5067/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of iron (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 4.81 micrograms per gram. The limit was not supplied by the laboratory used in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|92-494

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61ffb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|T. D. Martin

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Lead Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 17A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 17A and 17C represent the concentration of lead detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 17B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|200101
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/enddate|200902
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/current|observed
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/progress|Complete
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/update|As needed

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2008/5067/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of lead (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 0.48 micrograms per gram and 0.2 micrograms per gram in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e61fff.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|17A - Lead in dry weight (micrograms per gram) from largemouth bass (LMB; Micropterus salmoides), blue catfish (CAT; Ictalurus furcatus), and striped mullet (MUL; Mugil cephalus) collected from Davis Pond postdiversion sites from December 2007 through February 2009. The horizontal line represents the 85th percentile in dry weight from the National Contaminant Biomonitoring Program (Schmitt and Brumbaugh, 1990); for lead it is 0.76 micrograms per gram. For lead concentration data, see Figure 17C (Jenkins and others, 2011).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Magnesium Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 18A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 18A and 18C represent the concentration of magnesium detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 18B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|200101

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of magnesium (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 4.81 micrograms per gram. The limit was not supplied by the laboratory used in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|Christopher J. Schmitt
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|Vicki S. Blazer
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|Gail M. Dethloff

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161de4b063f258e62003.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).

The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Mercury Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 20A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 20A and 20C represent the concentration of mercury detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 20B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of mercury (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 0.16 micrograms per gram and 0.1 micrograms per gram in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6200b.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|20A - Mercury in dry weight (micrograms per gram) from largemouth bass (LMB; Micropterus salmoides), blue catfish (CAT; Ictalurus furcatus), and striped mullet (MUL; Mugil cephalus) collected from Davis Pond postdiversion sites from December 2007 through February 2009. The horizontal line represents the 85th percentile in dry weight from the National Contaminant Biomonitoring Program (Schmitt and Brumbaugh, 1990); for mercury it is 0.59 micrograms per gram. For mercury concentration data, see Figure 20C (Jenkins and others, 2011).

It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Nickel Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 22A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 22A and 22C represent the concentration of nickel detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 22B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of nickel (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 0.48 micrograms per gram and 0.5 micrograms per gram in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62013.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|22A - Nickel in dry weight (micrograms per gram) from largemouth bass (LMB; Micropterus salmoides), blue catfish (CAT; Ictalurus furcatus), and striped mullet (MUL; Mugil cephalus) collected from Davis Pond postdiversion sites from December 2007 through February 2009. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Selenium Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 23A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 23A and 23C represent the concentration of selenium detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 23B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of selenium (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 0.48 micrograms per gram and 0.6 micrograms per gram in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).
