52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|92-494
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lemoyne, PA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e62017.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|23A - Selenium in dry weight (micrograms per gram) from largemouth bass (LMB; Micropterus salmoides), blue catfish (CAT; Ictalurus furcatus), and striped mullet (MUL; Mugil cephalus) collected from Davis Pond postdiversion sites from December 2007 through February 2009. The horizontal line represents the 85th percentile in dry weight from the National Contaminant Biomonitoring Program (Schmitt and Brumbaugh, 1990); for selenium it is 2.52 micrograms per gram. For selenium concentration data, see Figure 23C (Jenkins and others, 2011).

It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Strontium Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 25A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 25A and 25C represent the concentration of strontium detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 25B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of strontium (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 0.48 micrograms per gram. The limit was not supplied by the laboratory used in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161ee4b063f258e6201f.xml|/metadata/distinfo/distliab|Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/origin|Heather M. Olivier

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Zinc Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 27A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 27A and 27C represent the concentration of zinc detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 27B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of zinc (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 1.01 micrograms per gram. The limit was not supplied by the laboratory used in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|92-494

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62027.xml|/metadata/distinfo/distliab|Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Total Polychlorinated Biphenyl (PCB) Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 5A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 5A and 5C represent the concentration of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 5B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Figure 5 is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected. PCB concentrations were below detectable levels for the majority of prediversion fish specimens tested (28 out of 36 samples). Minimum detection levels for PCBs were not declared in the 2008 or 2011 studies.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River, using electroshock and gill and hoop nets. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Samples were stored in precleaned jars and frozen (-20 degrees Celsius) until analysis. Automated extraction apparatus (ASE 200 Accelerated Solvent Extractor, Dionex, Sunnyvale, Calif.) was used with 0.5-15 g of tissue samples having been mixed with Hydromatrix (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, Calif.). Using 100 percent dichloromethane inside stainless steel extraction cells at 100 degrees Celsius and 200 pounds per square inch (psi), the extracts were dissolved and were collected in 60-milliliter (mL) glass vials and concentrated to 1-3 mL by using an evaporative solvent reduction apparatus (water bath or TurboVap II Evaporation System, Caliper Life Sciences, Hopkinton, Mass.). Sample aliquots were weighed for determining percentage of lipids, and the remaining portions were processed through a clean-up column (activated silica gel and alumina) and high-performance liquid chromatography to minimize matrix interference. Extracts concentrated to a final volume of 0.5 mL were submitted for determination of aliphatic, aromatic, and chlorinated hydrocarbons.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/geoform|journal article
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|Fresenius Journal of Analytical Chemistry
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|367
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Berlin
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|Springer
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: To test for organic contaminants in 2001, separation of OC pesticides and PCBs was done on a silicic acid chromatographic column following analysis by megabore column electron capture gas chromatography (Mississippi State Chemical Laboratory [MSCL] standard operating procedure [SOP] 1.267). Total PCBs were calculated by adding the sum of Aroclors 1242, 1248, 1254, and 1260. Postdiversion: Quantitation was performed on an HP model 5890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with electron capture detection (ECD). Between 1 and 5 mL of sample was injected by using an HP model 7673A autosampler. The primary capillary column was a J&W DB-5 (30-m x 24-mm ID and 0.25-mm film thickness). The second column, a confirmation column, was a J&W DB-17HT (30-m x 0.25-mm ID and 0.15-mm film thickness). The inlet system was splitless, and the carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. For the analysis of standard halogenated hydrocarbons, the temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min. The ramp rate was 5 degrees Celsius/min to 140 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min, followed by a ramp rate of 1.5 degrees Celsius/min to 250 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min and a ramp rate of 10 degrees Celsius/min to 300 degrees Celsius with a final hold time of 5 min. Additional column chromatography is required to separate polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) from toxaphene/pesticides and planar PCBs. An aliquot of the extract prior to clean-up with high-performance liquid chromatography was processed through a 3 percent deactivated silica gel column packed in dichloromethane, which was then flushed with pentane. The sample extract was transferred to the top of the column and flushed with 100 mL of pentane; this fraction contained PCBs and dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethanes (DDTs). This fraction was further processed by column chromatography packed with activated carbon/Celite (1:19 and 5 percent by weight) (World Minerals Inc., Santa Barbara, Calif.) and flushing with 1:4 dichloromethane/cyclohexane mixture. The instrument was operated in the splitless mode with helium as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius, held for 1 min. The ramp rate was 10 degrees Celsius/min to 150 degrees Celsius, followed by a ramp rate of 6.0 degrees Celsius/min to 270 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 3 min. The retention time of sample analytes fell within 15 seconds of the retention time of analytes in a calibration standard or retention index solutions. The levels of aroclor and toxaphene were determined by using retention index solutions of both complex mixtures. Aroclor were determined in a similar method to that described by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e6202f.xml|/metadata/distinfo/distliab|Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Total DDT Derivatives in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 6A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figure 6A represents the total DDT derivatives detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 6B compares prediversion and postdiversion levels of DDT (not including its derivatives). Figure 6C presents a graphical representation of the ratios of different DDT isomers found in Davis Pond postdiversion testing. It compares the ratios of DDT, DDE, and DDD found in the fish samples collected at Davis Pond from 2007-2009.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by different labs in the pre- and postdiversion studies. The lab used for the prediversion testing had a minimum detection limit of 0.010 ppm (parts per million) for DDT and its derivatives. Detection limits for postdiversion testing were 0.00001 except for one type of DDE, which had a detection limit of 0.00028 ppm. Please refer toTable 1 of the report, "Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Biomonitoring: Prediversion and Postdiversion Freshwater Fish Data" for a complete listing of detection limits for all DDT derivatives, pre- and postdiversion.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River, using electroshock and gill and hoop nets. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Samples were stored in precleaned jars and frozen (-20 degrees Celsius) until analysis. Automated extraction apparatus (ASE 200 Accelerated Solvent Extractor, Dionex, Sunnyvale, Calif.) was used with 0.5-15 g of tissue samples having been mixed with Hydromatrix (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, Calif.). Using 100 percent dichloromethane inside stainless steel extraction cells at 100 degrees Celsius and 200 pounds per square inch (psi), the extracts were dissolved and were collected in 60-milliliter (mL) glass vials and concentrated to 1-3 mL by using an evaporative solvent reduction apparatus (water bath or TurboVap II Evaporation System, Caliper Life Sciences, Hopkinton, Mass.). Sample aliquots were weighed for determining percentage of lipids, and the remaining portions were processed through a clean-up column (activated silica gel and alumina) and high-performance liquid chromatography to minimize matrix interference. Extracts concentrated to a final volume of 0.5 mL were submitted for determination of aliphatic, aromatic, and chlorinated hydrocarbons.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubdate|2001
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/title|National Coastal Assessment Quality Assurance Project Plan 2001-2004

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/geoform|journal article
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|Fresenius Journal of Analytical Chemistry
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|367
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Berlin
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|Springer
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: To test for organic contaminants in 2001, separation of OC pesticides and PCBs was done on a silicic acid chromatographic column following analysis by megabore column electron capture gas chromatography (Mississippi State Chemical Laboratory [MSCL] standard operating procedure [SOP] 1.267). Postdiversion: Quantitation was performed on an HP model 5890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with electron capture detection (ECD). Between 1 and 5 mL of sample was injected by using an HP model 7673A autosampler. The primary capillary column was a J&W DB-5 (30-m x 24-mm ID and 0.25-mm film thickness). The second column, a confirmation column, was a J&W DB-17HT (30-m x 0.25-mm ID and 0.15-mm film thickness). The inlet system was splitless, and the carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. For the analysis of standard halogenated hydrocarbons, the temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min. The ramp rate was 5 degrees Celsius/min to 140 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min, followed by a ramp rate of 1.5 degrees Celsius/min to 250 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min and a ramp rate of 10 degrees Celsius/min to 300 degrees Celsius with a final hold time of 5 min. Additional column chromatography is required to separate polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) from toxaphene/pesticides and planar PCBs. An aliquot of the extract prior to clean-up with high-performance liquid chromatography was processed through a 3 percent deactivated silica gel column packed in dichloromethane, which was then flushed with pentane. The sample extract was transferred to the top of the column and flushed with 100 mL of pentane; this fraction contained PCBs and dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethanes (DDTs). This fraction was further processed by column chromatography packed with activated carbon/Celite (1:19 and 5 percent by weight) (World Minerals Inc., Santa Barbara, Calif.) and flushing with 1:4 dichloromethane/cyclohexane mixture. The instrument was operated in the splitless mode with helium as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius, held for 1 min. The ramp rate was 10 degrees Celsius/min to 150 degrees Celsius, followed by a ramp rate of 6.0 degrees Celsius/min to 270 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 3 min. The retention time of sample analytes fell within 15 seconds of the retention time of analytes in a calibration standard or retention index solutions. The levels of aroclor and toxaphene were determined by using retention index solutions of both complex mixtures. Aroclor were determined in a similar method to that described by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|5285161fe4b063f258e62033.xml|/metadata/distinfo/distliab|Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Aluminum Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|figure
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Figures 9A, B, and C
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). Figures 9A and 9C represent the concentration of aluminum detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 9B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Sample analyses were performed by two different labs between the pre- and postdiversion studies. The detection limit of aluminum (in dry weight) in the prediversion study was 5.12 micrograms per gram and 2.0 micrograms per gram in the postdiversion analysis. Table is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: Analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 - 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). Postdiversion: Quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70-80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6203f.xml|/metadata/distinfo/distliab|Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Four-site Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) Results for Levels of Total Inorganic Contaminants in Fish Captured for Davis Pond Postdiversion Sampling, 2007-2009
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|spreadsheet
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Table 10
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001 - which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). This table presents the results of statistical analysis of variance of inorganic contaminants in fish sampled pre- and postdiversion of Davis Pond. Data collected consist of measurements of inorganic contaminants detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2001 (prediversion) and 2007-2009 (6-8 years postdiversion). Total amounts of inorganic contaminants were compared using two-way and three-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) tests. Inorganic contaminants tested for include aluminum, arsenic, barium, boron, cadmium, chromium, copper, iron, lead, magnesium, manganese, mercury, nickel, selenium, strontium, vanadium, and zinc. A four-site analysis was performed to compare levels of contamination in fish drawn from the Mississippi River, and those collected from three marsh sites (Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/idinfo/ptcontac/cntinfo/cntinst|Additional contact: Information Services, Voice 337-266-8692, E-mail nwrclibrary@usgs.gov
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Data in this table were derived from statistical ANOVA tests performed on contaminants data collected in other tables of the "Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Biomonitoring: Prediversion and Postdiversion Freshwater Fish Data," report, as well contaminants levels summarized in the earlier report, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." Accuracy of the information depends upon the accuracy of the underlying collected data taken from these reports, as well as the statistical techniques used to analyze the information for this table. Laboratory services were performed and facilitated by the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (GERG) at Texas A&M (prediversion) and Laboratory & Environmental Testing, Inc. (postdiversion). Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006). Statistical analyses were performed by trained scientists considered experts in this field.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. The period symbol "." indicates no significant interaction between the analyzed factors. Least squares means results are not spelled out in this table. Fields that contain "n.a." were not analyzed because valid comparisons could not be made due to differing detection levels between the labs used in the pre- and postdiversion analyses.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|During the Davis Pond pre-diversion lab testing, analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 degrees Celsius to 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). During Davis Pond postdiversion contaminants testing, quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70 to 80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer). For determination of methylmercury, the procedure was modified for tissue and based on EPA Method 1630 (2001). Methylmercury was defined as all methylmercury forms and species found in the digestate. Samples were digested with methanol and potassium hydroxide and then ethylated prior to analysis with a Model III cold-vapor atomic fluorescence spectrometer (Brooks Rand Labs, Seattle, Wash.) (EPA, 2001).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|T. D. Martin
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|C.A. Brockhoff
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|J.T. Creed
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|EMMC Methods Work Group
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubdate|1994

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62043.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|ANOVA tests were performed on the inorganic contaminants data collected. ANOVA analyzes variance to determine if a result is likely to be random or attributable to some causative factor. This table displays the likelihood of the observed variance in chemical contaminations arising by chance, expressed as p (probability) values. Low values indicate a significant result with a low probability of occurring randomly. Least squares means results are not spelled out in this table. Abbreviations: Spp = species Cat = blue catfish (Ictalurus furcatus) Mul= striped mullet (Mugil cephalus) Lmb= largemouth bass (Micropterus salmoides) Mi= Mississippi River Other = Lake Salvador, Lake Cataouatche, and Bayou Couba LS = Lake Salvador Cata = Lake Catouatche Couba = Bayou Couba Dot symbol (.)= indicates no significant interaction Asterisk symbol (*)= indicates interaction

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62049.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Table 3
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62049.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62049.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). This data set consists of fish health data from the largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62049.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62049.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Accuracy of measured values in the field is not based on a formal assessment. Determination of values are conducted by a experienced biologist. Lab measurements are conducted using calibrated equipment.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62049.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62049.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. The period symbol "." represents a lack of data for that parameter. This metadata record explains, whenever possible, why attribute data were missing.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62049.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field/Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e62049.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|From December 2007 through February 2009, fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Only fish within a predetermined length range were collected in order to target mature and similarly aged individuals. Observations were made on length (in centimeters), weight (in grams), internal and external body appearance, skin, surface, parasite incidence, organ color and condition, spleen and liver weight, gonadal sex and gonad condition, fin condition, and skeletal abnormalities. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995, 1999; Smith and others, 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma 1993). Age was estimated by using otoliths (Beckman and others, 1990; Nieland and Wilson, 1993; DeVries and Frie, 1996; Nieland and others, 2002) or fin spine increments (Ashley and Garling, 1980).

It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.
