52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Organochlorines Detected in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling, 2007-2009
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|tabular digital data
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Table 4
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). This data set consists of measurements of organochlorines detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. Table is complete and contains data where organochlorine concentrations were detected.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|From December 2007 through February 2009, fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Only fish within a predetermined length range were collected in order to target mature and similarly aged individuals. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995, 1999; Smith and others, 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Samples were stored in precleaned jars and frozen (-20 degrees Celsius) until analysis. Automated extraction apparatus (ASE 200 Accelerated Solvent Extractor, Dionex, Sunnyvale, Calif.) was used with 0.5-15 g of tissue samples having been mixed with Hydromatrix (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, Calif.). Using 100 percent dichloromethane inside stainless steel extraction cells at 100 degrees Celsius and 200 pounds per square inch (psi), the extracts were dissolved and were collected in 60-milliliter (mL) glass vials and concentrated to 1-3 mL by using an evaporative solvent reduction apparatus (water bath or TurboVap II Evaporation System, Caliper Life Sciences, Hopkinton, Mass.). Sample aliquots were weighed for determining percentage of lipids, and the remaining portions were processed through a clean-up column (activated silica gel and alumina) and high-performance liquid chromatography to minimize matrix interference. Extracts concentrated to a final volume of 0.5 mL were submitted for determination of aliphatic, aromatic, and chlorinated hydrocarbons.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/geoform|journal article
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|Fresenius Journal of Analytical Chemistry
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|367
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Berlin
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|Springer
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851620e4b063f258e6204c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Quantitation was performed on an HP model 5890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with electron capture detection (ECD). Between 1 and 5 mL of sample was injected by using an HP model 7673A autosampler. The primary capillary column was a J&W DB-5 (30-m x 24-mm ID and 0.25-mm film thickness). The second column, a confirmation column, was a J&W DB-17HT (30-m x 0.25-mm ID and 0.15-mm film thickness). The inlet system was splitless, and the carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. For the analysis of standard halogenated hydrocarbons, the temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min. The ramp rate was 5 degrees Celsius/min to 140 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min, followed by a ramp rate of 1.5 degrees Celsius/min to 250 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min and a ramp rate of 10 degrees Celsius/min to 300 degrees Celsius with a final hold time of 5 min. Additional column chromatography is required to separate polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) from toxaphene/pesticides and planar PCBs. An aliquot of the extract prior to clean-up with high-performance liquid chromatography was processed through a 3 percent deactivated silica gel column packed in dichloromethane, which was then flushed with pentane. The sample extract was transferred to the top of the column and flushed with 100 mL of pentane; this fraction contained PCBs and dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethanes (DDTs). This fraction was further processed by column chromatography packed with activated carbon/Celite (1:19 and 5 percent by weight) (World Minerals Inc., Santa Barbara, Calif.) and flushing with 1:4 dichloromethane/cyclohexane mixture. The instrument was operated in the splitless mode with helium as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius, held for 1 min. The ramp rate was 10 degrees Celsius/min to 150 degrees Celsius, followed by a ramp rate of 6.0 degrees Celsius/min to 270 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 3 min. The retention time of sample analytes fell within 15 seconds of the retention time of analytes in a calibration standard or retention index solutions. The levels of aroclor and toxaphene were determined by using retention index solutions of both complex mixtures. Aroclor were determined in a similar method to that described by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Two-site Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) Results for Levels of Total Organic Contaminants in Fish Captured for Davis Pond Postdiversion Sampling, 2007-2009
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|spreadsheet
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Table 7
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001 - which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). This table presents the results of statistical analysis of variance of organic contaminants in fish sampled pre- and postdiversion of Davis Pond. Data collected consist of measurements of organic contaminants detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2001 (prediversion) and 2007-2009 (6-8 years postdiversion). Total amounts of organic contaminants were compared using two-way and three-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) tests. Organic contaminants tested for include aliphatic hydrocarbons (AHs), polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), organochlorines (OCs), DDT, DDE, and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs). A two-site analysis was performed to compare levels of contamination in fish drawn from the Mississippi River, and those collected from all marsh sites (Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/idinfo/ptcontac/cntinfo/cntinst|Additional contact: Information Services, Voice 337-266-8692, E-mail nwrclibrary@usgs.gov
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Data in this table were derived from statistical ANOVA tests performed on contaminants data collected in other tables of the "Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Biomonitoring: Prediversion and Postdiversion Freshwater Fish Data," report, as well contaminants levels summarized in the earlier report, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." Accuracy of the information depends upon the accuracy of the underlying collected data taken from these reports, as well as the statistical techniques used to analyze the information for this table. Laboratory services were performed and facilitated by Mississippi State Chemical Lab (prediversion) and TDI-Brooks International, Inc. (postdiversion). Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006). Statistical analyses were performed by trained scientists considered experts in this field.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. The period symbol "." indicates no significant interaction between the analyzed factors. Least squares means results are not spelled out in this table. Fields that contain "n.a." were not analyzed because valid comparisons could not be made due to differing detection levels between the labs used in the pre- and postdiversion analyses.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|Christopher J. Schmitt
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|Vicki S. Blazer

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Samples were stored in precleaned jars and frozen (-20 degrees Celsius) until analysis. Automated extraction apparatus (ASE 200 Accelerated Solvent Extractor, Dionex, Sunnyvale, Calif.) was used with 0.5-15 g of tissue samples having been mixed with Hydromatrix (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, Calif.). Using 100 percent dichloromethane inside stainless steel extraction cells at 100 degrees Celsius and 200 pounds per square inch (psi), the extracts were dissolved and were collected in 60-milliliter (mL) glass vials and concentrated to 1-3 mL by using an evaporative solvent reduction apparatus (water bath or TurboVap II Evaporation System, Caliper Life Sciences, Hopkinton, Mass.). Sample aliquots were weighed for determining percentage of lipids, and the remaining portions were processed through a clean-up column (activated silica gel and alumina) and high-performance liquid chromatography to minimize matrix interference. Extracts concentrated to a final volume of 0.5 mL were submitted for determination of aliphatic, aromatic, and chlorinated hydrocarbons.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/geoform|journal article
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|Fresenius Journal of Analytical Chemistry
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|367
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Berlin
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|Springer
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkt|None
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Gas chromotography
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Mass spectrometry
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Electron capture detection
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Flame ionization detection
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Selected ion monitoring
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: To test for organic contaminants in 2001, analyses for AHs and PAHs were done by first digesting tissue with potassium hydroxide, then neutralizing, and then reconstituting in petroleum ether before transfer to a silica gel chromatography column. Eluates of AH and PAH residues were separated by eluting aliphatics from the column with petroleum ether followed by elution of aromatics with methylene chloride with petroleum ether mixture and then methylene chloride. This eluate was concentrated for quantification by capillary column, flame ionization gas chromatography (Mississippi State Chemical Laboratory [MSCL] standard operating procedure [SOP] 1.265). The aromatic hydrocarbon fraction was reconstituted in methylene chloride and quantified by gas chromatographymass spectroscopy (MSCL SOP 1.276). Separation of OC pesticides and PCBs was done on a silicic acid chromatographic column following analysis by megabore column electron capture gas chromatography (MSCL SOP 1.267). Total PCBs were calculated by adding the sum of Aroclors 1242, 1248, 1254, and 1260. Postdiversion: "Aliphatic Hydrocarbon Determination by Gas Chromatography/Flame Ionization Detection (GC/FID)" Target analytes were analyzed by using a Hewlett Packard (HP) model 5890 Series II Gas Chromatograph with a Flame Ionization Detector (Hewlett Packard Company, Palo Alto, Calif.) operated in a splitless mode. An HP-1MS capillary column (30-m x 0.25-mm inner diameter [ID] and 0.25-mm film thickness) was used to resolve peaks. The carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1.5 mL/minute (min). The temperature of the injection port was 300 degrees Celsius, and transfer line was 300 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 60 degrees Celsius, and the ramp rate was 12 degrees Celsius/min to a final oven temperature of 180 degrees Celsius. Normal alkanes with 10-34 carbons and the isoprenoids pristine and phytane were determined by using this procedure. "Aromatic Hydrocarbon Determination by Selected Ion Monitoring (SIM)-Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry (GC/MS)" Quantitation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and their alkylated homologues was done with a HP model 5890 GC and model 5972 MS operated in SIM by using a capillary column. The GC was operated in splitless mode, and the capillary column was an HP-5 ms (60-m x 0.25-mm ID and 0.25-mm film thickness) (Agilent Technologies). The carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The temperature of the injection port was 300 degrees Celsius, and transfer line was 290 degrees Celsius. The mass spectrometer scanned from 35 to 500 atomic mass units (amu) per second or less by utilizing 70 volts of electron energy in electron impact ionization mode. The relative peak heights of the primary mass ion compared to the confirmation or secondary mass ion fell within 30 percent of the relative intensities of these masses in a reference mass spectrum. "Organochlorine Determination by Gas Chromatography/Electron Capture Detection (ECD)" Quantitation was performed on an HP model 5890 GC equipped with an ECD. Between 1 and 5 mL of sample was injected by using an HP model 7673A autosampler. The primary capillary column was a J&W DB-5 (30-m x 24-mm ID and 0.25-mm film thickness). The second column, a confirmation column, was a J&W DB-17HT (30-m x 0.25-mm ID and 0.15-mm film thickness). The inlet system was splitless, and the carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. For the analysis of standard halogenated hydrocarbons, the temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min. The ramp rate was 5 degrees Celsius/min to 140 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min, followed by a ramp rate of 1.5 degrees Celsius/min to 250 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min and a ramp rate of 10 degrees Celsius/min to 300 degrees Celsius with a final hold time of 5 min. Additional column chromatography is required to separate polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) from toxaphene/pesticides and planar PCBs. An aliquot of the extract prior to clean-up with high-performance liquid chromatography was processed through a 3 percent deactivated silica gel column packed in dichloromethane, which was then flushed with pentane. The sample extract was transferred to the top of the column and flushed with 100 mL of pentane; this fraction contained PCBs and dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethanes (DDTs). This fraction was further processed by column chromatography packed with activated carbon/Celite (1:19 and 5 percent by weight) (World Minerals Inc., Santa Barbara, Calif.) and flushing with 1:4 dichloromethane/cyclohexane mixture. The instrument was operated in the splitless mode with helium as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius, held for 1 min. The ramp rate was 10 degrees Celsius/min to 150 degrees Celsius, followed by a ramp rate of 6.0 degrees Celsius/min to 270 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 3 min. The retention time of sample analytes fell within 15 seconds of the retention time of analytes in a calibration standard or retention index solutions. The levels of aroclor and toxaphene were determined by using retention index solutions of both complex mixtures. Aroclor were determined in a similar method to that described by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/pubdate|199712

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Two-way and three-way ANOVA (analyses of variance) were performed on the transformed data. 52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62057.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|ANOVA tests were performed on the organic contaminants data collected. ANOVA analyzes variance to determine if a result is likely to be random or attributable to some causative factor. This table displays the likelihood of the observed variance in chemical contaminations arising by chance, expressed as p (probability) values. Low values indicate a significant result with a low probability of occurring randomly. Least squares means results are not spelled out in this table. Abbreviations: Spp = species Cat = blue catfish (Ictalurus furcatus) Mul= striped mullet (Mugil cephalus) Lmb= largemouth bass (Micropterus salmoides) Mi= Mississippi River Other = Lake Salvador, Lake Cataouatche, and Bayou Couba DDT= dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane DDE= dichlorodiphenyldichloroethylene Dot symbol (.)= indicates no significant interaction Asterisk symbol (*)= indicates interaction

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001 - which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). This table presents the results of statistical analysis of variance of organic contaminants in fish sampled pre- and postdiversion of Davis Pond. Data collected consist of measurements of organic contaminants detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2001 (prediversion) and 2007-2009 (6-8 years postdiversion). Total amounts of organic contaminants were compared using two-way and three-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) tests. Organic contaminants tested for include aliphatic hydrocarbons (AHs), polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), organochlorines (OCs), DDT, DDE, and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs). A four-site analysis was performed to compare levels of contamination in fish drawn from the Mississippi River, and those collected from three marsh sites (Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Data in this table were derived from statistical ANOVA tests performed on contaminants data collected in other tables of the "Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Biomonitoring: Prediversion and Postdiversion Freshwater Fish Data," report, as well contaminants levels summarized in the earlier report, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." Accuracy of the information depends upon the accuracy of the underlying collected data taken from these reports, as well as the statistical techniques used to analyze the information for this table. Laboratory services were performed and facilitated by Mississippi State Chemical Lab (prediversion) and TDI-Brooks International, Inc. (postdiversion). Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006). Statistical analyses were performed by trained scientists considered experts in this field.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. The period symbol "." indicates no significant interaction between the analyzed factors. Least squares means results are not spelled out in this table. Fields that contain "n.a." were not analyzed because valid comparisons could not be made due to differing detection levels between the labs used in the pre- and postdiversion analyses.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Samples were stored in precleaned jars and frozen (-20 degrees Celsius) until analysis. Automated extraction apparatus (ASE 200 Accelerated Solvent Extractor, Dionex, Sunnyvale, Calif.) was used with 0.5-15 g of tissue samples having been mixed with Hydromatrix (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, Calif.). Using 100 percent dichloromethane inside stainless steel extraction cells at 100 degrees Celsius and 200 pounds per square inch (psi), the extracts were dissolved and were collected in 60-milliliter (mL) glass vials and concentrated to 1-3 mL by using an evaporative solvent reduction apparatus (water bath or TurboVap II Evaporation System, Caliper Life Sciences, Hopkinton, Mass.). Sample aliquots were weighed for determining percentage of lipids, and the remaining portions were processed through a clean-up column (activated silica gel and alumina) and high-performance liquid chromatography to minimize matrix interference. Extracts concentrated to a final volume of 0.5 mL were submitted for determination of aliphatic, aromatic, and chlorinated hydrocarbons.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkt|None
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Gas chromotography
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Mass spectrometry
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Electron capture detection
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Flame ionization detection
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methodid/methkey|Selected ion monitoring
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: To test for organic contaminants in 2001, analyses for AHs and PAHs were done by first digesting tissue with potassium hydroxide, then neutralizing, and then reconstituting in petroleum ether before transfer to a silica gel chromatography column. Eluates of AH and PAH residues were separated by eluting aliphatics from the column with petroleum ether followed by elution of aromatics with methylene chloride with petroleum ether mixture and then methylene chloride. This eluate was concentrated for quantification by capillary column, flame ionization gas chromatography (Mississippi State Chemical Laboratory [MSCL] standard operating procedure [SOP] 1.265). The aromatic hydrocarbon fraction was reconstituted in methylene chloride and quantified by gas chromatographymass spectroscopy (MSCL SOP 1.276). Separation of OC pesticides and PCBs was done on a silicic acid chromatographic column following analysis by megabore column electron capture gas chromatography (MSCL SOP 1.267). Total PCBs were calculated by adding the sum of Aroclors 1242, 1248, 1254, and 1260. Postdiversion: "Aliphatic Hydrocarbon Determination by Gas Chromatography/Flame Ionization Detection (GC/FID)" Target analytes were analyzed by using a Hewlett Packard (HP) model 5890 Series II Gas Chromatograph with a Flame Ionization Detector (Hewlett Packard Company, Palo Alto, Calif.) operated in a splitless mode. An HP-1MS capillary column (30-m x 0.25-mm inner diameter [ID] and 0.25-mm film thickness) was used to resolve peaks. The carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1.5 mL/minute (min). The temperature of the injection port was 300 degrees Celsius, and transfer line was 300 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 60 degrees Celsius, and the ramp rate was 12 degrees Celsius/min to a final oven temperature of 180 degrees Celsius. Normal alkanes with 10-34 carbons and the isoprenoids pristine and phytane were determined by using this procedure. "Aromatic Hydrocarbon Determination by Selected Ion Monitoring (SIM)-Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry (GC/MS)" Quantitation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and their alkylated homologues was done with a HP model 5890 GC and model 5972 MS operated in SIM by using a capillary column. The GC was operated in splitless mode, and the capillary column was an HP-5 ms (60-m x 0.25-mm ID and 0.25-mm film thickness) (Agilent Technologies). The carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The temperature of the injection port was 300 degrees Celsius, and transfer line was 290 degrees Celsius. The mass spectrometer scanned from 35 to 500 atomic mass units (amu) per second or less by utilizing 70 volts of electron energy in electron impact ionization mode. The relative peak heights of the primary mass ion compared to the confirmation or secondary mass ion fell within 30 percent of the relative intensities of these masses in a reference mass spectrum. "Organochlorine Determination by Gas Chromatography/Electron Capture Detection (ECD)" Quantitation was performed on an HP model 5890 GC equipped with an ECD. Between 1 and 5 mL of sample was injected by using an HP model 7673A autosampler. The primary capillary column was a J&W DB-5 (30-m x 24-mm ID and 0.25-mm film thickness). The second column, a confirmation column, was a J&W DB-17HT (30-m x 0.25-mm ID and 0.15-mm film thickness). The inlet system was splitless, and the carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. For the analysis of standard halogenated hydrocarbons, the temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min. The ramp rate was 5 degrees Celsius/min to 140 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min, followed by a ramp rate of 1.5 degrees Celsius/min to 250 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min and a ramp rate of 10 degrees Celsius/min to 300 degrees Celsius with a final hold time of 5 min. Additional column chromatography is required to separate polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) from toxaphene/pesticides and planar PCBs. An aliquot of the extract prior to clean-up with high-performance liquid chromatography was processed through a 3 percent deactivated silica gel column packed in dichloromethane, which was then flushed with pentane. The sample extract was transferred to the top of the column and flushed with 100 mL of pentane; this fraction contained PCBs and dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethanes (DDTs). This fraction was further processed by column chromatography packed with activated carbon/Celite (1:19 and 5 percent by weight) (World Minerals Inc., Santa Barbara, Calif.) and flushing with 1:4 dichloromethane/cyclohexane mixture. The instrument was operated in the splitless mode with helium as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius, held for 1 min. The ramp rate was 10 degrees Celsius/min to 150 degrees Celsius, followed by a ramp rate of 6.0 degrees Celsius/min to 270 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 3 min. The retention time of sample analytes fell within 15 seconds of the retention time of analytes in a calibration standard or retention index solutions. The levels of aroclor and toxaphene were determined by using retention index solutions of both complex mixtures. Aroclor were determined in a similar method to that described by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Two-way and three-way ANOVA (analyses of variance) were performed on the transformed data. Two-way ANOVA tests considered species and site as factors; three-way ANOVA tests considered time, site, and species as factors.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Transformed Contaminant Levels
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|ANOVA tests were performed on the organic contaminants data collected. ANOVA analyzes variance to determine if a result is likely to be random or attributable to some causative factor. This table displays the likelihood of the observed variance in chemical contaminations arising by chance, expressed as p (probability) values. Low values indicate a significant result with a low probability of occurring randomly. Least squares means results are not spelled out in this table. Abbreviations: Spp = species Cat = blue catfish (Ictalurus furcatus) Mul= striped mullet (Mugil cephalus) Lmb= largemouth bass (Micropterus salmoides) Mi= Mississippi River Other = Lake Salvador, Lake Cataouatche, and Bayou Couba LS = Lake Salvador Cata = Lake Catouatche Couba = Bayou Couba DDT= dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane DDE= dichlorodiphenyldichloroethylene Dot symbol (.)= indicates no significant interaction Asterisk symbol (*)= indicates interaction

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205b.xml|/metadata/distinfo/distliab|Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Two-site Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) Results for Levels of Total Inorganic Contaminants in Fish Captured for Davis Pond Postdiversion Sampling, 2007-2009
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|spreadsheet
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Data Series
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|604
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/othercit|Table 9
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/604/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001 - which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10). This table presents the results of statistical analysis of variance of inorganic contaminants in fish sampled pre- and postdiversion of Davis Pond. Data collected consist of measurements of inorganic contaminants detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2001 (prediversion) and 2007-2009 (6-8 years postdiversion). Total amounts of inorganic contaminants were compared using two-way and three-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) tests. Inorganic contaminants tested for include aluminum, arsenic, barium, boron, cadmium, chromium, copper, iron, lead, magnesium, manganese, mercury, nickel, selenium, strontium, vanadium, and zinc. A two-site analysis was performed to compare levels of contamination in fish drawn from the Mississippi River, and those collected from all marsh sites (Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Data in this table were derived from statistical ANOVA tests performed on contaminants data collected in other tables of the "Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Biomonitoring: Prediversion and Postdiversion Freshwater Fish Data," report, as well contaminants levels summarized in the earlier report, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." Accuracy of the information depends upon the accuracy of the underlying collected data taken from these reports, as well as the statistical techniques used to analyze the information for this table. Laboratory services were performed and facilitated by the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (GERG) at Texas A&M (prediversion) and Laboratory & Environmental Testing, Inc. (postdiversion). Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006). Statistical analyses were performed by trained scientists considered experts in this field.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling. The period symbol "." indicates no significant interaction between the analyzed factors. Least squares means results are not spelled out in this table. Fields that contain "n.a." were not analyzed because valid comparisons could not be made due to differing detection levels between the labs used in the pre- and postdiversion analyses.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Field
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel who used electroshock and gill and hoop nets from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet. Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methcite/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1992/0494/report.pdf
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis. Postdiversion: Tissue samples were homogenized after being freeze-dried, and wet and dry weights were used to determine percent moisture, as before. Tissues were digested in a closed Teflon (DuPont) vessel by using a microwave.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methtype|Lab
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/method/methdesc|During the Davis Pond pre-diversion lab testing, analysis for metals followed procedures contained in SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) of the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (tissue digestion SOPs 0006 and 9408 and analysis SOPs 9409 and 9802). For trace metals analyses, frozen samples were thawed, subsamples removed for percent dry weight and trace metals analyses, and subsamples were freeze dried. Tissues were macerated by using a Teflon (DupontTM) spatula, and the freeze-dried subsamples were ground to a fine powder, weighed to 0.1 mg, and transferred into a 50- mL polypropylene centrifuge tube. Concentrated sulfuric acid (2.5 mL) was added and vortexed, and then concentrated nitric acid (1.5 mL) was added and vortexed. The sample tube was capped loosely and then heated in a water bath at 90 degrees Celsius to 95 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. After cooling, distilled deionized water (10 mL) was added and vortexed, and then 5 percent (by weight) potassium permanganate (10 mL) and 5 percent (by weight) potassium persulfate (5 mL) were added to each tube. The tube was vortexed, capped tightly, and left overnight at room temperature (more than 12 hours). A sodium chloride/ hydroxylamine sulfate solution (5 mL) was added to reduce excess permanganate, and the digestate was brought to a final volume of 35 mL with deionized water prior to analysis. The tube was mixed until the manganese oxide particles were dissolved, and then samples were analyzed by using cold vapor atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Geochemical and Environmental Research Group SOP 006). During Davis Pond postdiversion contaminants testing, quantitation of metals was done according to the methods developed and accepted by U.S. Department of the Interior and generally accord with EPA Methods 200.7 (Martin and others, 1994) and 200.8 (Creed and others, 1994). For digestion, the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 5.0 mL trace metal grade nitric acid and 1 mL of high purity hydrogen peroxide. Samples were heated to 180 degrees Celsius, and after cooling, they were diluted to 50.0 mL. For digestion for arsenic and selenium, magnesium nitrate dry ash was used, and the normal sample weight was 0.500 g dw, with 10 mL trace metal grade nitric acid, 2 mL of trace metal grade hydrogen chloride (HCl), and 10 mL 40 percent magnesium nitrate hydrate in a 100 mL Pyrex (Corning Incorporated) beaker. Samples were refluxed overnight at 70 to 80 degrees Celsius and then heated to dryness and placed in a muffle furnace and ramped at 1 degree Celsius/min to 500 degrees Celsius and held for 1 h. After addition of 10 mL 50 percent HCl, samples were refluxed on a hot plate for 1 h, cooled, and diluted to 50 mL. Instrumentation for analyses included an Optima 7300 DV ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, Mass.) and atomic absorption by AAnalyst 600 with or without a FIA S1000 (Perkin Elmer). For determination of methylmercury, the procedure was modified for tissue and based on EPA Method 1630 (2001). Methylmercury was defined as all methylmercury forms and species found in the digestate. Samples were digested with methanol and potassium hydroxide and then ethylated prior to analysis with a Model III cold-vapor atomic fluorescence spectrometer (Brooks Rand Labs, Seattle, Wash.) (EPA, 2001).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e6205f.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|ANOVA tests were performed on the inorganic contaminants data collected. ANOVA analyzes variance to determine if a result is likely to be random or attributable to some causative factor. This table displays the likelihood of the observed variance in chemical contaminations arising by chance, expressed as p (probability) values. Low values indicate a significant result with a low probability of occurring randomly. Least squares means results are not spelled out in this table. Abbreviations: Spp = species Cat = blue catfish (Ictalurus furcatus) Mul= striped mullet (Mugil cephalus) Lmb= largemouth bass (Micropterus salmoides) Mi= Mississippi River Other = Lake Salvador, Lake Cataouatche, and Bayou Couba Dot symbol (.)= indicates no significant interaction Asterisk symbol (*)= indicates interaction

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|This dataset consists of a map depicting aquatic vegetation along the Natchez Trace Parkway. Four herbaceous aquatic alliances were manually mapped and aggregated as an aquatic vegetation class. Ground-based vegetation classification was provided by the National Park Service and mapped by the U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|To provide the National Park Service with a separate map of aquatic vegetation polygons in the Natchez Trace Parkway. This shapefile can be layered over the map of the Parkway to identify the location and National Vegetation Classification associations of aquatic vegetation.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/idinfo/useconst|Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) as a data source would be appreciated in products developed from these data. Such acknowledgement as is standard for citation and legal practices for data sources is expected by users of these data. Sharing new data layers developed directly from these data would be appreciated by the USGS NWRC staff. Users should be aware that comparison with other datasets for the same area from other time periods may be inaccurate because of inconsistencies resulting from changes in mapping conventions, data collection procedures, and computer processes over time. The distributor shall not be liable for improper or incorrect use of these data, based on the description of appropriate/inappropriate uses described in this metadata document. These data are not legal documents and are not to be used as such.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) would like to thank Paul Conzelman and Martha Segura of the National Park Service for allowing us the opportunity to contribute to the landcover mapping of the Nation's resources and Kurt Foote of the National Park Service for his guidance and vital help in our field reconnaissance. Partial funding for this work was provided through the U.S. National Park Service Agreement Number 14431A53200000. We are grateful to Steve Hartley (USGS) for his development of critical geographic information system (GIS) procedures and help in GIS processing. The USGS NWRC would also like to acknowledge Gulf Coast Aerial Mapping Co., Inc. for the generation of the aerial photography.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|National Vegetation Classification data compiled by the National Park Service (NPS) at ground sites throughout the Natchez Trace Parkway were used to assign the class descriptors in the landcover classifications. Out of the 331 total field sites there were 9 sites that fit into the aquatic vegetation classification. These sites represented 6 alliances that did not occur frequently enough to map with a high degree of accuracy. The researchers only digitally mapped the alliances that could be seen on the color infrared images; the aquatic vegetation on the map included fewer than half of the field sites originally marked aquatic vegetation (See Table 4 in 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway'). Additional points were added to the map that spectrally matched classified aquatic vegetation field sites.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Visual inspection and automated checking were performed on the data to confirm the integrity of the topology.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Aquatic vegetation noted by the National Park Service that were not distinguishable from adjacent vegetation were not digitized.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/timeinfo/mdattim/sngdate/caldate|20041015
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/srccurr|ground condition
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccitea|Filtered DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccontr|Filtered DOQQs used to minimize unwanted variability when classifying landcover
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Color infrared (CIR) aerial photography was acquired during leaf-on conditions. The flights occurred on September 29-30 and October 6 and 15, 2004. The resulting aerial film rolls were then scanned at 25 microns by using a true color, true optics scanner to generate a 1,000-dot per inch (dpi) product and converted to DOQQs. The effects of tilt and relief were removed from the aerial photos by orthorectification. The transformation of the photographic frames to DOQQ representation provided uniform scale. Uniform scale allowed the direct measure of true distance and direction. The tiles were then cut to match existing DOQQs in the UTM projection zones. The 235 DOQQs created from the 386 aerial frames were mosaiced to create full coverage of the Parkway. For ease of use, the DOQQs were grouped into 11 mosaics, each covering a section of the Parkway. At the request of the NPS, each mosaic was divided into ten tiles to allow for efficient loading on less robust computers. For more detailed information, see Appendix 2 of 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway.'
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|An 11 m by 25 m (average) spectral filter was applied to the DOQQs to produce a scale comparable to the 20 m by 50 m ground-plot size used by the National Park Service. This filter was applied to each of the 11 mosaic sections of the Parkway imagery. The filter minimized unwanted canopy variability (irregularly illuminated tree crowns and canopy gaps and associated shadowing) and maximized forest-stand identification.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|Filtered DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|In the field-site classifications received from the National Park Service (NPS), we grouped 9 of the 331 total field sites into an aquatic vegetation class. All six alliances included in this group were observed at one or two sites along the entire Parkway and were often of limited spatial extent. From a mapping perspective, it was highly unlikely these sites would be identified by using the unsupervised classification strategy. The sites that could be distinguished in the color infrared imagery were manually mapped and labeled aquatic vegetation.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62065.xml|/metadata/distinfo/distliab|Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/origin|Terri Bannister (Five Rivers Services, LLC at U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/origin|Elijah W. Ramsey III, Ph.D (U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubdate|2011
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/title|Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/geoform|report
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|2011-1276
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|This dataset represents aerial photography of the Natchez Trace Parkway that was taken in late September and early October of 2004. Images were acquired during leaf-on conditions as required by the National Park Service (NPS) to accomplish their ground-based vegetation classification. Nearly 400 aerial photography frames were scanned and orthorectified to generate digital orthophoto quarter quads (DOQQs). These were cut to match existing DOQQs creating a total of 235 DOQQs for the entire 715 km long Parkway. For ease of use, the DOQQs were grouped into 11 mosaics, each covering a section of the Parkway. At the request of the NPS, each mosaic was divided into ten tiles to allow for efficient loading on less robust computers.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of this dataset is to provide a data source for landcover mapping of the Natchez Trace Parkway for the USGS-NPS Vegetation Characterization Program. The USGS-NPS Vegetation Characterization Program is a cooperative effort by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Park Service (NPS) to classify, describe, and map vegetation communities in more than 280 national park units across the United States. This landmark program is both the first to provide national-scale descriptions of vegetation for a Federal agency and the first to create national vegetation standards for its data products. The vegetation mapping program is an important part of the NPS Inventory and Monitoring Program, a long-term effort to develop baseline data for all national park units that have a natural resource component. For more information visit the Vegetation Inventory Program (VIP) website at: http://science.nature.nps.gov/im/inventory/veg/index.cfm.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The following is a list of the digital orthophoto quarter quadrangles (DOQQs) for each mosaic: Mosaic 1 (Mississippi - Zone 15) - Natchez (NE, SE), Washington (NE, NW, SE, SW), Pine Ridge (SE), Cranfield (NW), Church Hill (NE, NW, SE, SW), Rodney (SE, SW), Lorman (NE, NW, SW), Red Lick (NW), Widows Creek (NE, SE), Port Gibson (NE, NW, SW), Willows (SE, SW), and Hermanville (NW). Mosaic 2 (Mississippi - Zone 15; this mosaic has been divided into Mosaic 2 South and Mosaic 2 North) - Carlisle (NE, NW, SE, SW), Utica West (NW), Big Black (SE), Cayuga (SE, NE, SW), Learned (NE, NW, SW), Edwards (SE), Terry NW (NW), Raymond (NE, SE, SW), Clinton (NE, NW, SW), Pocahontas (SE, SW), Jackson (NW), Ridgeland (NE, NW, SE, SW), Madison (NE, NW, SE, SW), and Canton (SE). Mosaic 3 South (Mississippi - Zone 16) - Goshen Springs (NW), Shoccoe (NE, NW, SE, SW), Sharon SE (NE, NW, SW), Farmhaven (NE, SE, SW), Ofahoma (NE, NW, SE, SW), Thomastown (NE, NW, SE, SW), Conway (NW), Joseph (NE, SE), Singleton (NW, SW), Kosciusko (NE, NW, SE, SW), McAdams (SE), Ethel North (NE, NW, SE,SW), Ethel South (NW), and Kosciusko NE (SE). Mosaic 3 North (Mississippi - Zone 16) - French Camp (NE, SE, SW), Weir (NE, NW, SW), Tomnolen (NE, SE, SW), Reform (NE, NW, SW), Sapa (NE, SE, SW), Maben (NE, NW, SW), Mantee (NE, NW, SE, SW), Montpelier (NW), Woodland (NE, SE), and Sparta (NE, NW, SW). Mosaic 4 South (Mississippi - Zone 16) - Houston East (NE, NW, SE, SW), Troy (NE, SE), Troy SE (NE, NW, SW), Bissell (NE, NW, SE, SW), Verona (NW), Sherman (NE, SE), and Tupelo (NE, NW, SW). Mosaic 4 North (Mississippi - Zone 16) - Tupelo (NE, NW, SW), Guntown (NE, SE, SW), Ratliff (NE, NW, SE, SW), Kirkville (NE, NW, SW), Marietta (SE), Fulton NE (NE, NW), Paden SE (NE, SE, SW), Belmont (NE, NW, SW), and Tishomingo (SE, SW). Mosaic 5 South (Alabama - Zone 16) - Bishop (NE, NW, SE, SW), Margerum (NE, SE), Barton (NW), Cherokee (NE, NW, SE, SW), Wright (SE), Sinking Creek (NW), Threet (NE, NW, SE, SW), and Pleasant Site (NW). Mosaic 5 North (Tennessee - Zone 16) - Cypress Inn (NE, NW, SE, SW), Westpoint (NW), Whitten (NW), Three Churches (NE, SE), Collinwood (NE, NW, SW), Waynesboro East (SE, SW), and Ovilla (NE, NW, SE, SW). Mosaic 6 (Tennessee - Zone 16) - Riverside (NE, SE, SW), Henryville (NE, NW, SW), Gordonsburg (NE, NW, SE, SW), Sunrise (SE), Mount Joy (NW), Greensfield Bend (NE, NW, SE, SW), and Williamsport (NE, NW, SW). Mosaic 7 (Tennessee - Zone 16) - Primm Springs (NE, NW, SE, SW), Theta (NE, NW, SE, SW), Fairview (NE, SE, SW), Leipers Fork (NW), Kingston Springs (SE), and Bellevue (SW).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/useconst|Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) as a data source would be appreciated in products developed from these data. Such acknowledgement as is standard for citation and legal practices for data sources is expected by users of these data. Sharing new data layers developed directly from these data would be appreciated by the USGS NWRC staff. Users should be aware that comparison with other datasets for the same area from other time periods may be inaccurate because of inconsistencies resulting from changes in mapping conventions, data collection procedures, and computer processes over time. The distributor shall not be liable for improper or incorrect use of these data, based on the description of appropriate/inappropriate uses described in this metadata document. These data are not legal documents and are not to be used as such.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) would like to thank Paul Conzelman and Martha Segura of the National Park Service for allowing us the opportunity to contribute to the landcover mapping of the Nation's resources and Kurt Foote of the National Park Service for his guidance and vital help in our field reconnaissance. Partial funding for this work was provided through the U.S. National Park Service Agreement Number 14431A53200000. We are grateful to Steve Hartley (USGS) for his development of critical geographic information system (GIS) procedures and help in GIS processing. The USGS NWRC would also like to acknowledge Gulf Coast Aerial Mapping Co., Inc. for the generation of the aerial photography.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Not applicable; data are not attributed
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|The flight path was designed to cover the 715 km length of the Natchez Trace Parkway. Data are complete as possible.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|The DOQQs are compliant with the digital orthophoto standard as defined by the U.S. Geological Survey Rocky Mountain Mapping Center.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Color infrared (CIR) aerial photography was acquired during leaf-on conditions. The flights occurred on September 29-30 and October 6 and 15, 2004. The resulting aerial film rolls were then scanned at 25 microns by using a true color, true optics scanner to generate a 1,000-dot per inch (dpi) product and converted to DOQQs. The effects of tilt and relief were removed from the aerial photos by orthorectification. The transformation of the photographic frames to DOQQ representation provided uniform scale. Uniform scale allowed the direct measure of true distance and direction. The tiles were then cut to match existing DOQQs in the UTM projection zones. The 235 DOQQs created from the 386 aerial frames were mosaiced to create full coverage of the Parkway. For ease of use, the DOQQs were grouped into 11 mosaics, each covering a section of the Parkway. At the request of the NPS, each mosaic was divided into ten tiles to allow for efficient loading on less robust computers. For more detailed information, see Appendix 2 of 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway.'
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/spdoinfo/direct|Raster
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851621e4b063f258e62069.xml|/metadata/spdoinfo/rastinfo/rasttype|Pixel
