52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/origin|Terri Bannister (Five Rivers Services, LLC at U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/origin|Elijah W. Ramsey III, Ph.D (U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center)
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubdate|2011
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Mapping Landcover of the Natchez Trace Parkway 2004-2005
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|raster digital data
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|2011-1276
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|This dataset consists of a map depicting the landcover of the Natchez Trace Parkway. The mapping output was created using mosaiced color infrared aerial photography of the Parkway. The map shows the distribution of 18 landcover classes based on the National Vegetation Classification Standard. Ground-based vegetation classification was provided by the National Park Service (NPS). The mapping output delineates grasses, road-developed areas, scrub-shrub, shrubland, plantation, water bodies, areas of white oak, oak, pine-oak, pine-cedar, pine-sweetgum, sweetgum (including sweetgum-oak), scattered trees, swamp forest, irregular classes, aquatic vegetation, invasive species, canopy gaps, and clouds. Total mapped area includes a 100 m buffer outside the park boundary. 235 digital orthophoto quarter quadrangles (DOQQs) were required to cover the entire 715 km long Parkway. For ease of use, the DOQQs were grouped into 11 mosaics, each covering a section of the Parkway. At the request of the NPS, each mosaic was divided into ten tiles to allow for efficient loading on less robust computers.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|The purpose of this dataset is to provide an accurate depiction of the Natchez Trace Parkway landscape using the National Vegetation Classification Standard. This map is part of the USGS-NPS Vegetation Characterization Program, a cooperative effort by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Park Service (NPS), to classify, describe, and map vegetation communities in more than 280 national park units across the United States. This landmark program is both the first to provide national-scale descriptions of vegetation for a Federal agency and the first to create national vegetation standards for its data products. The vegetation mapping program is an important part of the NPS Inventory and Monitoring Program, a long-term effort to develop baseline data for all national park units that have a natural resource component. For more information visit the Vegetation Inventory Program (VIP) website at: http://science.nature.nps.gov/im/inventory/veg/index.cfm.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The following is a list of the digital orthophoto quarter quadrangles (DOQQs) for each mosaic: Mosaic 1 (Mississippi - Zone 15) - Natchez (NE, SE), Washington (NE, NW, SE, SW), Pine Ridge (SE), Cranfield (NW), Church Hill (NE, NW, SE, SW), Rodney (SE, SW), Lorman (NE, NW, SW), Red Lick (NW), Widows Creek (NE, SE), Port Gibson (NE, NW, SW), Willows (SE, SW), and Hermanville (NW). Mosaic 2 (Mississippi - Zone 15; this mosaic has been divided into Mosaic 2 South and Mosaic 2 North) - Carlisle (NE, NW, SE, SW), Utica West (NW), Big Black (SE), Cayuga (SE, NE, SW), Learned (NE, NW, SW), Edwards (SE), Terry NW (NW), Raymond (NE, SE, SW), Clinton (NE, NW, SW), Pocahontas (SE, SW), Jackson (NW), Ridgeland (NE, NW, SE, SW), Madison (NE, NW, SE, SW), and Canton (SE). Mosaic 3 South (Mississippi - Zone 16) - Goshen Springs (NW), Shoccoe (NE, NW, SE, SW), Sharon SE (NE, NW, SW), Farmhaven (NE, SE, SW), Ofahoma (NE, NW, SE, SW), Thomastown (NE, NW, SE, SW), Conway (NW), Joseph (NE, SE), Singleton (NW, SW), Kosciusko (NE, NW, SE, SW), McAdams (SE), Ethel North (NE, NW, SE,SW), Ethel South (NW), and Kosciusko NE (SE). Mosaic 3 North (Mississippi - Zone 16) - French Camp (NE, SE, SW), Weir (NE, NW, SW), Tomnolen (NE, SE, SW), Reform (NE, NW, SW), Sapa (NE, SE, SW), Maben (NE, NW, SW), Mantee (NE, NW, SE, SW), Montpelier (NW), Woodland (NE, SE), and Sparta (NE, NW, SW). Mosaic 4 South (Mississippi - Zone 16) - Houston East (NE, NW, SE, SW), Troy (NE, SE), Troy SE (NE, NW, SW), Bissell (NE, NW, SE, SW), Verona (NW), Sherman (NE, SE), and Tupelo (NE, NW, SW). Mosaic 4 North (Mississippi - Zone 16) - Tupelo (NE, NW, SW), Guntown (NE, SE, SW), Ratliff (NE, NW, SE, SW), Kirkville (NE, NW, SW), Marietta (SE), Fulton NE (NE, NW), Paden SE (NE, SE, SW), Belmont (NE, NW, SW), and Tishomingo (SE, SW). Mosaic 5 South (Alabama - Zone 16) - Bishop (NE, NW, SE, SW), Margerum (NE, SE), Barton (NW), Cherokee (NE, NW, SE, SW), Wright (SE), Sinking Creek (NW), Threet (NE, NW, SE, SW), and Pleasant Site (NW). Mosaic 5 North (Tennessee - Zone 16) - Cypress Inn (NE, NW, SE, SW), Westpoint (NW), Whitten (NW), Three Churches (NE, SE), Collinwood (NE, NW, SW), Waynesboro East (SE, SW), and Ovilla (NE, NW, SE, SW). Mosaic 6 (Tennessee - Zone 16) - Riverside (NE, SE, SW), Henryville (NE, NW, SW), Gordonsburg (NE, NW, SE, SW), Sunrise (SE), Mount Joy (NW), Greensfield Bend (NE, NW, SE, SW), and Williamsport (NE, NW, SW). Mosaic 7 (Tennessee - Zone 16) - Primm Springs (NE, NW, SE, SW), Theta (NE, NW, SE, SW), Fairview (NE, SE, SW), Leipers Fork (NW), Kingston Springs (SE), and Bellevue (SW).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/useconst|Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) as a data source would be appreciated in products developed from these data. Such acknowledgement as is standard for citation and legal practices for data sources is expected by users of these data. Sharing new data layers developed directly from these data would be appreciated by the USGS NWRC staff. Users should be aware that comparison with other datasets for the same area from other time periods may be inaccurate because of inconsistencies resulting from changes in mapping conventions, data collection procedures, and computer processes over time. The distributor shall not be liable for improper or incorrect use of these data, based on the description of appropriate/inappropriate uses described in this metadata document. These data are not legal documents and are not to be used as such.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|National Vegetation Classification data compiled by the National Park Service (NPS) at ground sites throughout the Natchez Trace Parkway were used to assign the class descriptors in the landcover classifications. A minimum of 30 independent accuracy assessment points per landcover was desired; however, this was not reached for all landcover classes. Further, ground sites were often sparse in regions of the Parkway. The lack of an adequate number of sites per class and the sparseness of the sites prevented the creation of two assessment sets; one for assigning class and one for accuracy assessment. Because of this, classification accuracy assessments used the same NPS data to assign class descriptors. The overall accuracy of the landcover classes was estimated to be 74%.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Not applicable

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/typesrc|digital database file
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|2005
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/timeinfo/rngdates/enddate|2010
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/srccurr|observed
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccitea|Unsupervised classification
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccontr|Preliminary landcover classification
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|An 11 m by 25 m (average) spectral filter was applied to the DOQQs to produce a scale comparable to the 20 m by 50 m ground-plot size used by the National Park Service. This filter was applied to each of the 11 mosaic sections of the Parkway imagery. The filter minimized unwanted canopy variability (irregularly illuminated tree crowns and canopy gaps and associated shadowing) and maximized forest-stand identification.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|Filtered DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|An unsupervised classification (accomplished numerically and impartially with little human input) was performed on the eleven mosaic sections of the Parkway. This process involved aggregating the pixels into spectral groupings, or clusters, based solely on the spectral distribution present in the image. The analyst then determined the landcover identity of these spectral groups by associating the classified image data with ground reference data from the National Park Service classification and notes from field reconnaissance missions. For more details, see the methods section in 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway.'
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Filtered DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|NPS Field Sites
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|Unsupervised classification
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e6206d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|The final mapping of the Parkway involved both machine processes (unsupervised classification) and human analysis (supervised classification). As a first step, shadows, edge and gap, were isolated and replaced on the map. Steps were taken to minimize the abrupt changes that occur between mosaiced orthophotos. Cutlines were compensated for by creating masks at the borders between orthophotos and applying classification algorithms only in the masked areas. The modified data were classified using an unsupervised classification algorithm. Progressive clustering techniques were used to separate and group clusters with mixed identities until all possible groups had been identified. The leftover clusters were labeled irregular classes on the map legend. Once all possible spectrally distinct classes had been identified, the final set of classes was migrated to the next adjacent mosaic section. A single signature migration was not applied from one end of the Parkway to the other; however, a mixture of progressive mapping classifications and signature migrations were applied throughout the Parkway. In a continued effort to generate a map product conforming to requests by the National Park Service, different filters were applied to the mapping output in order to reduce mapping artifacts, such as isolated pixel groups and ribbons. As a final step, an assessment of mapping accuracy was completed to provide an overall estimate of mapping performance. Field site observations were compared to the generated landcover map and the accuracy reported in contingency tables. Lastly, mapping outputs were then divided into 10 tiles per mosaic section at the request of the National Park Service. For more details see the Final Mapping Classification section in 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway.'

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e62071.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|This dataset represents the center points of 379 aerial photography frames taken of the Natchez Trace Parkway. The color infrared photography was flown in late September and early October of 2004 during leaf-on conditions as required by National Park Service (NPS) personnel to accomplish their ground-based landcover classification.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e62071.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|To spatially identify the aerial photograph frame centers captured for the Natchez Trace Parkway landcover mapping project.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e62071.xml|/metadata/idinfo/useconst|Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) as a data source would be appreciated in products developed from these data. 52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e62071.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) would like to thank Paul Conzelman and Martha Segura of the National Park Service for allowing us the opportunity to contribute to the landcover mapping of the Nation's resources and Kurt Foote of the National Park Service for his guidance and vital help in our field reconnaissance. Partial funding for this work was provided through the U.S. National Park Service Agreement Number 14431A53200000. We are grateful to Steve Hartley (USGS) for his development of critical geographic information system (GIS) procedures and help in GIS processing. The U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center would like to acknowledge the Gulf Coast Aerial Mapping Co., Inc. for the generation of the aerial photography.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851622e4b063f258e62071.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|To ensure complete photographic coverage of the Natchez Trace Parkway, images were taken with a 60 percent end lap. This dataset does not include the 9 additional images taken of the Vicksburg National Military Park. The flight path was designed to cover the 715 km length of the Natchez Trace Parkway.

The flights occurred on September 29-30 and October 6 and 15, 2004. Photographic centers were collected during the flights and delivered with the data.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|This dataset consists of a map depicting the distribution of irregular classes along the Natchez Trace Parkway. Irregular classes are those forest alliances that were usually represented by one or two field sites. In addition, these alliances did not align with any of the major forest classes and for the most part did not contain species that were common to other alliances. Ground-based vegetation classification was provided by the National Park Service and mapped by the U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|To provide the National Park Service with a separate map of irregular class polygons in the Natchez Trace Parkway. This shapefile can be layered over the map of the Parkway to identify the location and National Vegetation Classification associations of irregular classes.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/idinfo/useconst|Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) as a data source would be appreciated in products developed from these data. 52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|National Vegetation Classification data compiled by the National Park Service (NPS) at ground sites throughout the Natchez Trace Parkway were used to assign the class descriptors in the landcover classifications. Out of the 331 total field sites there were 30 sites that did not fit into any of the major landcover classifications. These sites represented 12 alliances that did not occur frequently enough to map with a high degree of accuracy. The analysts attempted to manually map the 12 alliances by identifying unique spectral keys, but were not successful. Eventually the researchers only digitally mapped the alliances that could be seen on the color infrared images; this irregular class on the map included fewer than half of the field sites originally marked irregular (See Table 2 in 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway'). Additional points were added to the map that spectrally matched classified irregular field sites.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Visual inspection and automated checking were performed on the data to confirm the integrity of the topology.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Irregular classes noted by the National Park Service that were not distinguishable from adjacent vegetation were not digitized.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccitea|Filtered DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccontr|Filtered DOQQs used to minimize unwanted variability when classifying landcover
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Color infrared (CIR) aerial photography was acquired during leaf-on conditions. The flights occurred on September 29-30 and October 6 and 15, 2004. The resulting aerial film rolls were then scanned at 25 microns by using a true color, true optics scanner to generate a 1,000-dot per inch (dpi) product and converted to DOQQs. The effects of tilt and relief were removed from the aerial photos by orthorectification. The transformation of the photographic frames to DOQQ representation provided uniform scale. Uniform scale allowed the direct measure of true distance and direction. The tiles were then cut to match existing DOQQs in the UTM projection zones. The 235 DOQQs created from the 386 aerial frames were mosaiced to create full coverage of the Parkway. For ease of use, the DOQQs were grouped into 11 mosaics, each covering a section of the Parkway. At the request of the NPS, each mosaic was divided into ten tiles to allow for efficient loading on less robust computers. For more detailed information, see Appendix 2 of 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway.'
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|An 11 m by 25 m (average) spectral filter was applied to the DOQQs to produce a scale comparable to the 20 m by 50 m ground-plot size used by the National Park Service. This filter was applied to each of the 11 mosaic sections of the Parkway imagery. The filter minimized unwanted canopy variability (irregularly illuminated tree crowns and canopy gaps and associated shadowing) and maximized forest-stand identification.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|Filtered DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|In the field-site classifications received from the National Park Service (NPS), we grouped 30 of the 331 total field sites into an “irregular occurrence” class. Twelve of the 15 alliances included in this group were observed at one to a few sites along the entire Parkway and were often of limited spatial extent. From a mapping perspective, it was highly unlikely these sites would be identified by using the unsupervised classification strategy. For these isolated and comparatively rarely occurring alliances, we formed a spectral key for each and subsequently used a supervised classification strategy to locate other occurrences of that alliance throughout the Parkway. These targeted, supervised classifications were not successful. No spectral key created for these individual alliances provided a unique signature, which is necessary for successful mapping. The high spectral variability and common features of these alliances on color infrared image data prevented determination of unique spectral keys. Where a spectral hue or texture could be identified at the NPS-defined field-site location of the irregular class, manual mapping was performed.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62085.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|Filtered DOQQs

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|This dataset consists of linear features depicting the main road running through the Natchez Trace Parkway and other roads visible on the color infrared photography. The Parkway is a 715-km roadway that historically connected the southern portions of the Mississippi River to the salt licks in central Tennessee. The vector data represent the roadway of the Parkway at an approximate along-track (parallel and perpendicular to the road) with a spatial accuracy of about 3 meters or less.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|To provide the National Park Service with a vector representation of the Natchez Trace Parkway and intersecting/nearby roads. This shapefile can be layered over the map to identify the location of roads along the Natchez Trace Parkway.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/idinfo/accconst|It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center and not indirectly through other sources which may have been changed in some way. 52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/idinfo/useconst|Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) as a data source would be appreciated in products developed from these data. Such acknowledgement as is standard for citation and legal practices for data sources is expected by users of these data. Sharing new data layers developed directly from these data would be appreciated by the USGS NWRC staff. Users should be aware that comparison with other datasets for the same area from other time periods may be inaccurate because of inconsistencies resulting from changes in mapping conventions, data collection procedures, and computer processes over time. The distributor shall not be liable for improper or incorrect use of these data, based on the description of appropriate/inappropriate uses described in this metadata document. These data are not legal documents and are not to be used as such.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) would like to thank Paul Conzelman and Martha Segura of the National Park Service for allowing us the opportunity to contribute to the landcover mapping of the Nation's resources and Kurt Foote of the National Park Service for his guidance and vital help in our field reconnaissance. Partial funding for this work was provided through the U.S. National Park Service Agreement Number 14431A53200000. We are grateful to Steve Hartley (USGS) for his development of critical geographic information system (GIS) procedures and help in GIS processing. The USGS NWRC would also like to acknowledge Gulf Coast Aerial Mapping Co., Inc. for the generation of the aerial photography.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|Linear attributes were accurately measured by GIS software. All linear features that are not part of the main Parkway were labeled 'other roads.'
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Visual inspection and automated checking were performed on the data to confirm the integrity of the topology.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|The entire Natchez Trace Parkway was driven while GPS points were accquired and later mapped. Linear features labeled as 'other roads' were manually mapped from color infrared photography. Where portions of these 'other roads' couldn't be seen in the imagery (e.g., covered by tree canopy) they were not mapped and therefore appear unconnected to the main Parkway.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|The accuracy of the horizontal positions is based on the accuracy of the GPS unit used and the post-processing of the points. Garmin specifications for the GPSMAP 176C: position less than 15 meters (95% of the time) and velocity of 0.05 meter/sec steady state. See the Garmin website for further specifications (http://www.garmin.com).

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/typesrc|digital database file
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/timeinfo/sngdate/caldate|2004
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/srccurr|ground condition
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccitea|Parkway Vector
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccontr|Vector data of the main Parkway
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Color infrared (CIR) aerial photography was acquired during leaf-on conditions. The flights occurred on September 29-30 and October 6 and 15, 2004. The resulting aerial film rolls were then scanned at 25 microns by using a true color, true optics scanner to generate a 1,000-dot per inch (dpi) product and converted to DOQQs. The effects of tilt and relief were removed from the aerial photos by orthorectification. The transformation of the photographic frames to DOQQ representation provided uniform scale. Uniform scale allowed the direct measure of true distance and direction. The tiles were then cut to match existing DOQQs in the UTM projection zones. The 235 DOQQs created from the 386 aerial frames were mosaiced to create full coverage of the Parkway. The resulting file was too large for most computers to handle and was split into 11 mosaics and then further subdivided into tiles (10 tiles/mosaic). For more detailed information, see Appendix 2 of 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway.'
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Driving along the Parkway at 45 miles per hour, GPS points were taken in a continuous stream mode using a GARMIN GPSMAP 176C. The GPS unit was hooked to an external antenna attached to a vehicle and plugged into a laptop with a serial connection. National Marine Electronic Association (NMEA) sentences from the GPS were recorded every 2 seconds. The points were then converted into vector format by extracting latitude and longitude from the NMEA sentences. The geographic coordinates were converted to shapefiles by using embedded X tools in Arcview 3.2. The vector data was then modified to delete all off-road stops.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|Parkway Vector
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62089.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Roads that intersect or are adjacent to the Parkway were digitized manually from color infrared photography. Where portions of these secondary and intersecting roads couldn't be seen in the imagery (e.g., covered by tree canopy) they were not mapped and therefore appear unconnected to the main Parkway.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|This dataset consists of a map depicting the distribution of sweetgum-oak mixed forests along the Natchez Trace Parkway. Ground-based vegetation classification was provided by the National Park Service and mapped by the U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center. In the final version of "Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway," the Sweetgum-Oak class was merged with the Sweetgum class because most of the time it co-occurred with the Sweetgum field sites.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|To provide the National Park Service with a separate map of Sweetgum-Oak class polygons in the Natchez Trace Parkway. This shapefile can be layered over the map of the Parkway to identify sweetgum-oak mixed forest locations.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/taxonomy/taxonsys/classsys/classcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://www.itis.gov/index.html
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/taxonomy/taxonsys/taxonpro|National Park Service (NPS) personnel provided ground-based identification of a small sample of sweetgum-oak mixed forests based upon their expertise and pre-existing knowledge of tree identification. An unsupervised classification was then performed on the filtered orthophotos of the Natchez Trace Parkway that identified many distinct spectral groups. The analyst correlated the field site data with the unsupervised classification and identified one of these spectral groups as sweetgum-oak. All other areas of similar spectra were also classified as sweetgum-oak.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/taxonomy/taxonsys/taxoncom|The trees identified in this dataset are classified as sweetgum and oak (Alliance codes = A.234, A.291, and A.292) in the 1998 National Vegetation Classification Standard (NVCS). The NVCS classifies similar species together into alliances and associations. Association is the finest floristic level in the NVCS; an alliance represents an aggregation of associations. A single association includes a variety of plants that share similar habitat and physiognomy. It is usually identified by a diagnostic species, in this case, sweetgum and oak. In this dataset, the sweetgum and oak associations include a variety of species and subspecies.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/useconst|Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) as a data source would be appreciated in products developed from these data. Such acknowledgement as is standard for citation and legal practices for data sources is expected by users of these data. Sharing new data layers developed directly from these data would be appreciated by the USGS NWRC staff. Users should be aware that comparison with other datasets for the same area from other time periods may be inaccurate because of inconsistencies resulting from changes in mapping conventions, data collection procedures, and computer processes over time. The distributor shall not be liable for improper or incorrect use of these data, based on the description of appropriate/inappropriate uses described in this metadata document. These data are not legal documents and are not to be used as such.

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), National Wetlands Research Center (NWRC) would like to thank Paul Conzelman and Martha Segura of the National Park Service for allowing us the opportunity to contribute to the landcover mapping of the Nation's resources and Kurt Foote of the National Park Service for his guidance and vital help in our field reconnaissance. 52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|2011-1276
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Lafayette, LA
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|National Vegetation Classification data compiled by the National Park Service (NPS) at ground sites throughout the Natchez Trace Parkway were used to assign the class descriptors in the landcover classifications. A minimum of 30 independent accuracy assessment points per landcover was desired; however, this was not reached for all landcover classes. In this case, twenty-five points were identified by the NPS as sweetgum-oak mixed forests. The unsupervised algorithm identified 17 of these points correctly, resulting in a 68 percent accuracy rate. For more information, see Table 5 in 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway.'
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|Visual inspection and automated checking were performed on the data to confirm the integrity of the topology.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This unsupervised classification of sweetgum-oak had an omission error rate of 32 percent. Comparison with National Park Service data suggested that many instances of sweetgum were misclassified as other landcover classes (omission error rate of 70 percent). Because of the underreporting of sweetgum, the final map output grouped sweetgum with sweetgum-oak (an alliance frequently grouped with sweetgum in unsupervised classification).
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/origin|Gulf Coast Aerial Mapping Co., Inc.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/pubdate|Unpublished material
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/title|Digital Orthoimagery for Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway 2004
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/geoform|raster digital data

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccite/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2011/1276/

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/timeinfo/mdattim/sngdate/caldate|20040930
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/timeinfo/mdattim/sngdate/caldate|20041006
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/timeinfo/mdattim/sngdate/caldate|20041015
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srctime/srccurr|ground condition
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccitea|Filtered DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/srcinfo/srccontr|Filtered DOQQs used to minimize unwanted variability when classifying landcover
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Color infrared (CIR) aerial photography was acquired during leaf-on conditions. The flights occurred on September 29-30 and October 6 and 15, 2004. The resulting aerial film rolls were then scanned at 25 microns by using a true color, true optics scanner to generate a 1,000-dot per inch (dpi) product and converted to DOQQs. The effects of tilt and relief were removed from the aerial photos by orthorectification. The transformation of the photographic frames to DOQQ representation provided uniform scale. Uniform scale allowed the direct measure of true distance and direction. The tiles were then cut to match existing DOQQs in the UTM projection zones. The 235 DOQQs created from the 386 aerial frames were mosaicked to create full coverage of the Parkway. The resulting file was too large for most computers to handle and was divided into 11 mosaics. These 11 mosaic sections, at the request of the National Park Service (NPS), were further subdivided into tiles (10 tiles/mosaic) only for NPS use. For more detailed information, see Appendix 2 of 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway.'
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|An 11 m by 25 m (average) spectral filter was applied to the DOQQs to produce a scale comparable to the 20 m by 50 m ground-plot size used by the National Park Service. This filter was applied to each of the 11 mosaic sections of the Parkway imagery. The filter minimized unwanted canopy variability (irregularly illuminated tree crowns and canopy gaps and associated shadowing) and maximized forest-stand identification.
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcused|DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|Unknown
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/srcprod|Filtered DOQQs
52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|An unsupervised classification (accomplished numerically and impartially with little human input) was performed on the images produced from the generated DOQQs. This process involved aggregating the pixels into spectral groupings, or clusters, based solely on the spectral distribution present in the image. The analyst then determined the landcover identity of the sweetgum-oak spectral groups by associating the classified image data with ground reference data from the National Park Service (NPS) classification and notes from field reconnaissance missions. When other areas of similar spectra were distinguishable, the pixels were also classified as sweetgum-oak. This shapefile was an interim product for the NPS created before the final completion of the map. In the final mapping output, sweetgum-oak was grouped with sweetgum. For more details, see 'Mapping the Natchez Trace Parkway.'

52714770e4b0f7a10664fce3|52851623e4b063f258e62091.xml|/metadata/distinfo/distliab|Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.
